arrival_beach_wake.text:
You wake on damp sand, ears ringing. The sky is gray. The ocean breathes beside you, indifferent.

Your name feels distant. Your past? Fragmented. But something hums beneath your skin—a presence, a pattern, like words you almost remember.

Footsteps approach.

arrival_beach_rescue.text:
"Another one." A woman's voice, calm and practiced. "Can you stand?"

You nod. Two figures help you to your feet: one wears traveler's leathers, the other a worn tunic marked with faded guild symbols.

"The inn's not far," the woman says. "You'll want answers. Everyone does."

inn_arrival.text:
The Threshold Inn sits just past the dunes, solid wood and warm light. Inside, a handful of arrivals sit nursing drinks or staring at their hands. You're shown to a table.

A middle-aged man in crisp robes approaches. His smile is professional, reassuring.

"Welcome. I'm Cerel, integration specialist. You probably have a lot of questions. Don't worry, that is normal. Unfortunately, I cannot answer them all but I can help you learn the basics on how to survive in this world."

inn_orientation_cerel.text:
Cerel explains:

The Floors are layered zones, each with towns, wilderness, and a guardian gate to the next level. You're on Floor Zero—the starting point. Safe, but limited.

Most arrivals can't remember their past clearly. That's normal. What matters now is forward.

You'll grow stronger through experience. Levels, skills, equipment—all real, all measurable. The system acknowledges your progress.

"Think of this as… a second chance. Or a test. Depends who you ask."

inn_orientation_dana.text:
A scarred woman at the bar interjects, not looking up from her drink.

"Cerel makes it sound clean. It's not. Floors get harder. Monsters get meaner. Parties help, but they also slow you down—shared rewards, shared risk."

She finally glances your way. "Name's Dana. Been here since the start. My advice? Pick your class carefully. It's not possible to change it later. And don't rush Floor One alone, if you plan on surviving, you should at least have a companion to help you."

class_overview.text:
Cerel nods. "Class selection is permanent for most. It shapes your combat style, your growth, your role in a party."

He gestures to a worn chart on the wall:

**Warrior**: Frontline durability. High HP, solid defense. Reliable damage, shield skills.

**Rogue**: Speed and precision. Lower HP, high evasion. Strong single-target burst.

**Mage**: Ranged magic. Fragile, but devastating area attacks. MP-hungry.

**Commoner**: Unspecialized. Balanced stats, no clear strengths. A challenge run for veterans.

"Take your time. This choice matters."

class_select.text:
Cerel watches you, waiting.

"When you're ready, speak your choice. The system will… acknowledge it. You'll feel the shift."

class_confirm.text:
A pulse runs through you—recognition, alignment. Your body feels… defined. Solid. Real.

Cerel smiles. "Good. Now let's see if you can use it."

trial_setup.text:
Cerel leads you outside, past the inn's training yard. A small fenced enclosure holds a single restless creature—a shoreline scavenger, teeth bared, eyes wild.

"Standard trial. One-on-one. I'll observe, but I won't intervene. Defeat it, and we'll talk about what comes next."

He steps back. The gate opens.

"Your move."

trial_victory_reflect.text:
The creature collapses. You're breathing hard, adrenaline fading. Then—

**Level 2.**

The sensation is immediate: clarity, strength, capacity. Your wounds knit slightly. Your energy stabilizes.

Cerel nods. "There it is. Growth. Each level makes you more resilient, more capable. But the curve flattens quickly—Level 10 takes far longer than Level 2."

Dana calls from the doorway. "And your MP resets after every fight. Convenient, right? HP doesn't. Plan accordingly."

party_intro.text:
Cerel gestures you back inside. Two figures wait at your table.

The first is a young woman with a fire staff slung across her back. She offers a small, confident nod. "Emma. Mage. I handle crowds and blast the critters from a distance."

The second is a lean man in dark leather, daggers sheathed at his belt. He grins. "Niale. Rogue. I handle... problems. Quietly."

Cerel explains: "Most Floor Zero exits are done in pairs or trios. Parties share rewards, but they also share risk. You'll split experience, but you'll survive encounters that would flatten you solo."

Dana adds from across the room: "And someone can watch your back while you drink a potion. Don't underestimate that."

Emma and Niale both look at you expectantly.

Cerel: "Your call. Pick one for now. The other will be around if you need them later."

companion_choice.text:
Emma: "I can burn groups down fast. Just keep them off me."

Niale: "I'm quick, I hit hard, and I know when to run. Your call."

Who do you choose?

companion_solo.text:
"I'll handle this alone," you say.

Emma shrugs. "Your call. We'll be around."

Niale nods. "Good luck."

Cerel frowns slightly. "Ambitious. Solo runs are riskier, but you'll keep all the rewards. Just remember: parties exist for a reason. You can recruit later if you change your mind."

Dana calls out: "And don't forget—knowledge is still valuable even solo. Study your enemies. Learn their patterns."

solo_path_skip_party_battle.text:
Cerel decides to skip the multi-enemy training exercise. "You've proven you can handle yourself one-on-one. For a solo run, that's the core skill. Multi-enemy encounters will be tougher without backup, but you'll learn through experience."

He gestures toward the inn. "Let's talk strategy instead."

solo_knowledge_intro.text:
Inside, Dana offers some advice.

"Solo means no Party Talk in combat, but you can still learn. Pay attention to enemy behavior. HP estimates, attack patterns, weaknesses—it all matters. Some enemies telegraph their moves. Use that."

Cerel nods. "Knowledge is survival. Even more so when you're alone. Floors have libraries, wandering scholars, other adventurers willing to share intel. Always worth the investment."

companion_emma_join.text:
Emma grins. "Good choice. Let's not die."

Niale shrugs. "Fair. I'll be around if you change your mind."

Cerel: "Excellent. Let's test the synergy."

companion_niale_join.text:
Niale nods. "Smart. I won't slow you down."

Emma raises an eyebrow. "Your funeral. I'll be at the bar if you need a real damage dealer."

Cerel: "Alright. Let's see how you work together."

companion_both_join.text:
"I'll take you both," you say.

Emma and Niale exchange a look.

Emma: "Alright. More hands, more options."

Niale: "Works for me. Just don't get in each other's way."

Cerel raises an eyebrow. "A full party from the start. Ambitious. Rewards split three ways, but your tactical options multiply. Let's see how you coordinate."

battle_party_setup.text:
Cerel leads you back outside. This time, the enclosure holds three scavengers, circling, coordinating.

"Party combat. Watch the turn order. Communicate. And remember—your companions know things you don't. Ask them."

The gate opens.

party_after_battle.text:
The last creature falls. You're winded, but intact. Your companions catch their breath.

Cerel approaches. "Well done. That's the foundation: solo capability, party coordination, and growth through conflict."

Dana joins him. "And if you're smart, you'll use that Party Talk option in fights. Your companions might know enemy weaknesses, behavior patterns, or tactical advice. It's free intel and doesn't cost your turn."

knowledge_intro_party_talk.text:
One of your companions speaks up:

"Dana's right. I've fought things like this before. If you're ever unsure in combat, just ask—I'll tell you what I know. No guarantees, but it beats guessing."

Cerel nods. "Knowledge is survival here. The more you learn, the better your odds. Some floors have libraries, some have wandering scholars. Always worth the detour."

Dana smirks. "Speaking of detours..."

protoquest_offer.text:
Dana leans against the doorway. "There's a rumor. Shoreline ruins, not far from here. Someone said they saw a supply cache—potions, maybe a weapon. Could be worth checking before you head to Floor One."

Your companion glances at you. "Optional. We don't need it, but free loot is free loot."

Cerel: "Entirely your call. The Floor One gate is open when you're ready. No rush."

Do you pursue the rumor?

protoquest_accept.text:
"Alright," you say. "Let's check it out."

Dana nods. "Smart. I'll mark it on your map. Don't take too long—ruins attract scavengers."

effects.message: The shoreline ruins are now accessible via Travel. Return to Floor One gate when ready.

protoquest_decline.text:
"We'll pass," you say. "Let's keep moving."

Dana shrugs. "Your call. Floor One's waiting."

Your companion nods. "Fair. Let's go."

effects.message: Floor One gate is now accessible via Travel. Explore at your own pace.

floor1_open_handoff.text:
Cerel walks you to the edge of the settlement. Beyond, a shimmering threshold marks the boundary to Floor One.

"This is where I leave you," he says. "Floor One is larger, more dangerous, and more rewarding. Towns exist, but they're farther apart. The guardian waits at the far end—defeat it, and Floor Two opens."

Your companion adjusts their gear. "No turning back now. Let's see what this place has."

effects.message: Chapter 00 complete. Explore Floor One and build your strength.

ch00_complete.text: The tutorial is complete. Floor One awaits. Your journey has just begun.

protoquest_ruins_entry.text:
The shoreline ruins are half-buried in sand, their stones worn by salt and time. Your companion scans the area.

"Quiet. Too quiet. Stay sharp."

A shape moves in the shadows—another scavenger, larger than the trial ones.

protoquest_complete.text:
The scavenger falls. Behind it, a weathered chest. Inside: a small potion and a handful of gold.

You pocket the loot. "Not bad. Let's head back."

Dana will be pleased.

effects.message: Optional objective complete. Return to Floor One gate when ready.
